title: 'Believe in your teammate, believe in each other': Patrick Mahomes was mic'd up for a powerful speech ahead of Chiefs' winning drive
text:
The Kansas City Chiefs rallied in the fourth quarter to defeat the Detroit Lions 34-30 on Sunday.

The game was won when reigning NFL MVP Patrick Mahomes led the Chiefs down the field for a touchdown in the final two minutes.

Just before the Chiefs' game-winning drive, Mahomes gave his teammates an emotional speech, calling on them to be themselves and trust in each other.

Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.

The Kansas City Chiefs were pushed to the brink against the Detroit Lions on Sunday before eventually pulling out a 34-30 victory.

After the Lions took the lead with just over two minutes remaining, reigning NFL MVP Patrick Mahomes and the Chiefs offense were left with one chance to drive the field to win the game and remain undefeated.

Just before taking the field, Mahomes gave his offense a pep talk that was caught on camera.

Read more: NFL POWER RANKINGS: Where every team stands heading into Week 5

"We do not have to do anything else other than being ourselves," Mahomes began. "I truly believe that. If we just be ourselves and trust in each other, we will go down there, we can put points up, we can do what we do."

"Don't try to go out there and do everything for yourself. Believe in your teammate. Believe in each other. And when we get these opportunities, we'll go down and find a way to win the game. Let's do it right here. Let's go."

—Kansas City Chiefs (@Chiefs) September 30, 2019

Mahomes' call to action worked, as the Chiefs navigated a 13-play, 79-yard drive in two minutes to take the lead with a one-yard touchdown run from Darrel Williams with just 20 seconds remaining, stealing the win from the Lions in Detroit.

NFL fans already knew Mahomes was a special player, but moments like his rallying speech on Sunday have Chiefs fans excited that they might have a dynasty coming together in Kansas City.

description: Patrick Mahomes is quite the leader when the Chiefs are on the field. His speech on Sunday proved he's a great leader on the sidelines as well.
